title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: It was the motive power that invested their daily routinewith so much of its liveliness and variety of aspect. In thedwellings of the wealthy and the great life might stagnate,health and spirits might pall and grow vapid, but in PipeLane there was always something going, something astir;for there, ' on the spur o' the moment,' Mrs. Molony wouldhave a party; 'on the spur o' the moment' Mr. Molony wouldremove all the furniture in the house to the pawnshop ; ' onthe spur o' the moment' Mrs. Maguire would buy herself anew imitation seal-skin jacket and hat; ' on the spur o' themoment' Billy Maguire would curse the Pope, and bear theconsequences ; ' on the spur o' the moment,' all four, and allPipe Lane, would raise a general ' strike' at the Mill; andnow, upon this self-same 'spur o' the moment,' it was decidedthat Maggie and Lotta should emigrate together to NewYork City, where they were sure to be met by Tim Molony,who knew how to put them both in the fair way of pushingtheir fortunes.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: ' It's all quare over here in Germany,' pursued Maggie. ' An' Lottie, she says it's me be's the furriner now, an'not her, an' that's the quarest of it all ! An' I'm lyin' wakin',thinkin' at nights what 'ud my da say, an' what 'ud BillyMaguire say, an' them ivvery wan down to wee HeneryJames, if they know'd I was here, and not in New YorkCity a-pushin' my fortun' wi' our Tim! They'd ate mealive if they know'd it, an' know'd I had lost my trunk, unlessthey thought I was foundthered at say, or swallied up in aniceberg—an' then there'd be a purty girnin' in Pipe Lane !What ought a body to do, mem? Besides, mem, I'mthinkin' long for Pipe Lane, an' wee Henery James, an'Eliza Jane, an' them ivvery wan, forby the Spinnin' Room,'and Maggie's voice shook.

snippet: ' Tut, tut! that wouldn't do,' cried Mrs. Molony brusquely,' for in coorse 't would have to be Orange lilies. Them'sthe only flowers as grows in Pipe Lane. An' then 't wouldbe the Papishers a' cloddin' of stones we'd have, and thePeelers out.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: After this neither spoke for some time, but each had ananxious look on her face, and Maggie rose from her dinnermore than once to step out to the street, and, shading hereyes with her hand, to scan the space between the two rowsof whitewashed houses, known as Pipe Lane, for some traceof her father—but in vain.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: Them's none o' their consarns. Lottie cudn't larn me them, because she bayn't long acquaint with the daycent English langwidge ; an' there wasnone o' them goin' much in Pipe Lane.'

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: But I'm fond o' Lottie, an'her godmother's a daycent ould body; an' betwixt themthey've lamed me to knit, an' bake, an' wash, an' iron, an'dig, an' scrub, an' clane. Oh law ! sich claynin' ! snippet: The funeral took place on Saturday afternoon, and wasduly attended by the Molonies, and by most of the otherinhabitants of Pipe Lane, who turned out willingly for theoccasion, although most of them had had no acquaintancewhatever with the deceased.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: These were Maggie's injunctions to a group of comradescoming from the spinning-room of Pipe Lane Factory. They had gathered round the door of the Schneiders'house; and with their bare feet in the rain-puddle, andtheir heads hooded in their checkered shawls, they peeredinquisitively towards the little window on the first floor, wherea small yellow blind was drawn closely down.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: Found rny da and my ma, William Maguire, Esquire,my brother-in-law, and Eliza Jane and wee Henery Jamesall to the fore and well. Didn't stay with the ladies inLondon, but come on right through, thinkin' long for themall, for Pipe Lane and the spinnin'-room, where there arefewer hands nor before. I begin work at my old placeMonday first, and hope to get on well.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: AVhen the cortege arrived at the corner of Pipe Lane itwas met by a demonstration of another kind; in the front aswarthy-faced man in a purple-and-gold sash, tottering underthe weight of a gigantic drum; next, a bandy-legged, leantailor, piping a well-known melody upon a tin flute; and,at his heels, a throng of men and boys tramping along in asort of irregular quick march. It was the Pipe LaneOrange Lodge starting for the usual Saturday's walk, withBilly Maguire as leader.
